s.text: As he moves to shore up his right-wing credentials, his more authentically conservative rivals are trying to establish their own credibility in the eyes of moderate Republicans.
Conservatives who were annoyed by Newt's nice-guy act were truly outraged when he suggested that one way to get a balanced-budget agreement might be to put off tax cuts.
In a caucus meeting last week, Gingrich reportedly said that Republican critics who complained he had no agenda "weren't smart enough to understand it."

In keeping with conservative newspeak, Gingrich referred to these as the taxes on "savings and job creation" and the tax on "death benefits."
The paradox is that while a deal would shore up Newt's position, he hasn't got enough power to negotiate one.

In an hour-long speech to GOPAC Monday night, he boasted about the Contract With America's influence in Mongolia.
